text:
S-X2
332. Cossar, Mary Elizabeth (Mrs. Hugh)
PIONEER DIET: WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN PIONEERS EAT?

Instructions: Please answer as many of these questions as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask. where it will be preserved as part of the permanent record of our Province.

Name ..........................................
Address ..........................................
Birthplace .........................................

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? ..........................................
Where did you set up housekeeping? ..........................................
Where had you been living before that? ..........................................
For how many people did you prepare meals? ..........................................
How far was it to your nearest store? ..........................................
How often could a visit be made to the store? ..........................................
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years?
Flour, sugar, tea, spices, raising animals, dried fruits, jam, marmalade.

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? ..........................................
In what quantities did you buy it? ..........................................
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? ..........................................
How much did you use graham flour? ..........................................
Whole wheat flour? ..........................................
Was flour milled locally? How far away? What year? ..........................................
What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? ..........................................
What other grain products did you use? ..........................................
Cornmeal? Whole Wheat? Farina? Other? ..........................................
Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? ..........................................
How did you grind it? ..........................................
PIONEER DIET: WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN FARMERS EAT?

Instructions: Please answer as many of these questions as you can and mail it to us.

Saskatchewan Archives Office, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask., where it will be preserved as part of the permanent record of our Province.

Name: Mrs. H. Cossar

Address: [illegible]

Birthplace: [illegible]

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start homesteading in Western Canada? ...1913

Where did you set up homestead? ...[illegible]

How far had you been living before that? ...[illegible]

For how many people did you prepare meals? ...[illegible]

How far was it to your nearest store? ...[illegible]

How often could a visit be made to the store? ...[illegible]

What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years? ...[illegible]

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? ...[illegible]

In what quantities did you buy it? ...[illegible]

What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? ...[illegible]

How much did you use graham flour? ...[illegible]

Whole wheat flour? ...[illegible]

Was flour milled locally? ...[illegible]

What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? ...[illegible]

What other grain products did you use? ...[illegible]

Cornmeal? ...[illegible]

Other? ...[illegible]

Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? ...[illegible]

How did you grind it? ...[illegible]
3. SUGAR AND SYRUP

In what quantity did you buy white sugar? (e.g., 20 lb. packs or 100 lbs.)
That was the price for a ten pound sack of white sugar? (e.g., $5.00 per 100 lbs.)
What brand of golden corn syrup did you use?
What size of tin of syrup did you usually buy? (e.g., 1 lb. tin)
At what price?

4. DAIRY PRODUCTS

How did you get a supply of fresh milk in the early days?
Butter? (e.g., homemade)
That was the price of butter? (e.g., $1.00 per lb.)
Did you keep eggs for interest? (e.g., how many?)
Did you make butter? (e.g., cheese? No)
What kind of cheese?

5. MEAT AND FISH

What was your meat supply in the early years? (e.g., beef, pork)
How did you get fresh meat? (e.g., butchering)
How often did you get fresh meat? (e.g., twice a year)
How did you preserve meat? (e.g., salting, smoking, pickling)
Was there a "beef ring" in your neighborhood? (e.g., until late 19th century)
If so, what year was it organized? (e.g., around 1870)
Did you use game? (e.g., ducks, moose)
For how long?
What part did fish play in the family diet? (e.g., dried, smoked)
Was the fish fresh, cured, or canned? (e.g., canned mostly—salmon)
Kinds? (e.g., occasionally, fresh and/or canned—spring)
6. BEVERAGES

What kind of tea did you buy? Red Rose, no label. At what price? $0.50 per lb.

What kind of coffee did you buy? (beans or ground) Ground.

Price? $0.25 per lb.

That other beverages were used?

7. VEGETABLES AND DRIED FRUITS

What was the price of potatoes per bushel when you set up housekeeping?

Could you get potatoes at the store? Yes.

If not, where from? Grocer's store.

What year did you first grow your own supply for the winter of:

Potatoes, Cabbage, Carrots, Onions, Turnips, Beets — Always.

In what quantities did you buy white navy beans? 10 lbs.

How did you buy prunes, (in bulk or by the box)? By the box.

What weight? 1 lb.

How did the grocer handle prunes (by box)? 1 lb.

What was the price of prunes? $0.50 per lb.

What other dried fruits did you use in the earliest days? (apricots, pears, apricots, peaches, loganberries, raisins, currants or others)?

8. PRESERVING

In the early years did you preserve any foods by drying? Peas, corn, beans, Saskatoons.

Other foods? No.

What year did you first preserve fruit by canning? Always had lots of it.

What year did you first preserve vegetables by canning? About 1920.

What year did you first preserve meat by canning? 1920.

Do you still preserve foods by canning or drying? Yes.

To what extent?

Did you make your own vinegar? Yes, several times.

Canning of fruits, vegetables & meat were not done in early years. Fruit was cooked by open kettle method.
6. What kind of tea did you buy? Red Brier.

7. What was the price of potatoes per bushel, etc.? Mr. Brown's market?

8. In what quantities did you buy? (In bulk or by the box?)

9. How did you buy prunes? (In bulk or by the box?)

10. What weight?

11. What was the price of prunes?

12. Just other dried fruit (or did you use in the earliest days? apricots, peaches, raisins, figs, etc.)

13. Do you still preserve foods by canning or drying?

14. To that extent?

15. Did you make any?

16. Canning of fruits, vegetables, meat, etc., was not done in early years. How was canned food made?
9. PLEASE FILL IN THE FOLLOWING TO THE BEST OF YOUR MEMORY:

| Macaroni              | about 1920                                     |                                                 |                                   |                     |

| Common salt           |                                               |                                                 |                                   |                     |
| Lily white syrup      |                                               |                                                 |                                   |                     |
| Toilet soap           | occasionally fancy wrapped in boxes of 3 cakes |                                                 |                                   |                     |
| Baking powder         | always                                         |                                                 |                                   |                     |
| Baking soda           |                                               |                                                 |                                   |                     |
| Dried peas            |                                               |                                                 |                                   |                     |
| Dried corn            |                                               |                                                 |                                   |                     |
| Vinegar               | always                                         |                                                 |                                   | quart or gal.       |

| - seedless            |                                               |                                                 |                                   | also pints bought in 2 lb. boxes |
| Rice                  |                                               |                                                 |                                   | 2 or 5 lbs.         |
| Currants              |                                               |                                                 |                                   |                     |
| Store jam - kinds?    | Raspberry, straw berry, gooseberry etc.        |                                                 |                                   | 4 lb. tin           |
| Cheese (Cheddar or store cheese) | always | by the pound. |                     |
| Vanilla               | always                                         |                                                 |                                   | small bottle        |

10. BAKING

What type of yeast did you use? Royal Yeast Co.

Did you make yeast for your own use? Using starter?

Using hops? Salt rising?

Did you buy baking powder? Baking soda?

Cream of tartar? Did you make your own baking powder?

Note: One family used the cones off the grey willows to make yeast in place of using hops.

10. BAKING

What type of yeast did you use? Rayal Yeast Bakers
Did you make yeast for your own use? Using starter
using hops?
Salt rising?
Baking soda?
Cream of tartar?

Note: The family used the grey willows to make yeast in place of using hops.
11. PLEASE FILL IN THE FOLLOWING TO THE BEST OF YOUR MEMORY:

12. WATER SUPPLY

Where did you get water for drinking and for cooking? (well, river, slough, dugout) *from hand dug wells, later from town bore.*

How far was this water from your home? *In the yard*..............

How was it brought to the home? (pail, barrel, tank) *pail*.............

Regarding water supply, mention any changes which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

*Most people have cisterns to take the place of the old rain or snow barrel & worse still having to soften slough or well water for washing purposes.*

12. WATER SUPPLY

Where did you get water for drinking and for cooking? (well, river, dugout)

How far was this water from your home?

How was it brought to the house? (pail, barrel, tank)

Regarding water supply, mention any changes which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

Most people have water from dugout or well. Some have water from river.
13. SOAPS

Did you buy laundry soap or make your own? Both

If you made your own, did you use lye? Yes, wood ashes?

What kinds of laundry soap did the grocer handle? Royal Crown, Tide Naptha

The wrappers off Royal Crown soap were exchanged for premiums.

14. FUEL

Suitable for framing compound, scions, flowers, fruit, killing etc.

What fuel did you use in the earliest days? Wood

Where did you get your fuel? From the lumbermen by...

Mention any changes in the use of fuels which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

Coal is used increasingly, with some kerosene oil stoves. Wood is very scarce owing to land clearing.

15. METHODS OF COOKING AND TYPES OF UTENSILS

For cooking, did you use an indoor fireplace or open hearth in the earliest days? (Give dates) ...

Did you use an outdoor fireplace or bake oven? (Give dates) ...

By whom was your first cook stove made? "Hunt Empire"

What year was it purchased? ... Price? ...

What types of utensils did you use? (Iron, copper, tin, homemade) Iron, tin, enamel, laté, aluminum

For preparing food? (china, earthenware, wooden bowls, other) China, earthenware, wooden butter bowls etc.

When did you first see enamel ware? ... As a child

Aluminum? ... Around 1927

Several sets of "Weaver" aluminum were sold into this district about 1920 and much of it is still in use.
13. Soaps

Did you buy laundry soap or make your own? 

If you made your own, did you use lye? 

What kinds of laundry soap did the grocer supply? 

What fuel did you use in the earliest days? 

Have you got your fuel? 

Has there been any change in the use of fuel which have taken place since you first started housekeeping? 

First started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

14. Methods of cooking and types of utensils

For cooking, did you use an indoor fireplace or open hearth? In the earliest days? (Give dates) 

Did you use an outdoor fireplace or bake oven? 

By whom was your first cook stove made? 

What year was it purchased? 

What types of utensils did you use? (Iron, copper, tin, homemade) 

For preparing food? (china, earthenware, wooden bowls, other)

When did you first see enamel ware? 

Aluminum? 

Several sets of "worn out" aluminum were sold in this district about 1920 and much of it still in use.
16. WRAPPINGS AND CONTAINERS

Mention any changes which you recall in the wrappings and containers received with the food you purchased (give dates where possible).

Waxed paper linings in cardboard containers.

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner and supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

Winter - Breakfast - cold cuts, fried potatoes, bread & butter - tea.

1945 - Dinner - Potatoes, turnips, gravy, pickles, hot roast beef, rice or steam pudding or perhaps dried fruit pie - tea.

Possibly hard cheese etc.

Supper - fried potatoes, meat, bread & butter, fruit & cake or biscuits - tea.

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in Western Canada? .......

Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at the time.

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

No.

Note: All details above are offered approximately.

e.g., custard pies were common too. Fresh berries - wild or season, also garden varieties of currants etc.

Pork was not too common but some pork was used.

My grandmother made hop yeast, soft soap etc. But times were different when I started housekeeping.
16. WRAPPERS AND CONTAINERS

Mention any changes which you recall in the wrappings and containers received with the food you purchased (give dates where possible).

17. Give a typical day's menu: (breakfast, dinner and supper) For the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

1941:
- **Breakfast**: two cups tea, toast, potatoes, bread & butter, tea.
- **Dinner**: potatoes, ham, peas, pudding or pie, fruit.
- **Supper**: fresh potatoes, meat, bread, butter, fruit, cake or biscuits.

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in Western Canada? Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at the time.

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

Note: All details about our offal diet appear monthly.

e.g., last week pigs were commonest. Thank heavens—will.

m. assam, also under varieties of curries etc.

Pork was not too common but since you've been sick.

my grandmothers make hop yeast, apple sauce etc. But

times were different when I started housekeeping
20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

Most people have refrigerators or deep freezers now. In early days milk was set in pans. Butter kept in crocks. Very little canned goods were available or fresh fruits, prepared mixes or canned meats etc. That is, nearly everything had to be prepared at home & directions used in amounts for lack of storage facilities. Cupboards were scarce. Kitchens inconvenient, no electricity available, lighting often poor & supplies had to be purchased in large quantities. There was usually purchasing for the winter.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homegrown and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

Very few prepared foods were used here before 1930 or even later. Although some people bought cases of fruit & of course jams were used. But most people baked their own bread & baked pies, cakes & cookies. Mixes were unknown. Canned tomatoes were among the first prepared foods I remember.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandising, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. (Use back of page if more space is needed).

As a child I remember my mother trading butter at the store using this method: The butter was made into a roll of perhaps from 4-8 lbs. Carefully rolled by a cheesecloth which had been dipped in cold water and then securely wrapped in fresh rhubarb leaves to keep it cool.

Most people brought their main supplies from a distance of 100 miles & made semi annual trips which took about a week with a team & wagon. They took a supply of food both for themselves & their team. Camped out even at night if a stopping place wasn't convenient.
20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

Most people have refrigerators or deep freezers these days. You could keep milk out in pans, but in earlier days you had to make sure the milk was cool. Fresh produce was purchased in season and made into salads. Everything had to be prepared at home. Cupboards were used in an attempt to store food, but not always successfully. Cupboards were used in an attempt to store food, but not always successfully.

21. How did you begin to rely on purchased foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

Very few purchased foods were used before 1930. Although some people bought canned goods, very little was used. Most people baked their own breads and pies. Others bought canned goods when they were available. Some bought canned goods when they were available.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandising, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. (Use back of page if more space is needed).

As a child I remember my mother taking walks to the store to buy milk. The milk was made into a well known brand. This milk was carefully selected by a chemist who had been appointed to test and ensure its quality. We supplied our fresh milk to farmers to keep it cool. Most people bought their main supplies from a store located in the middle of town. They would walk there twice a week with a wagon. They liked to supply their little farm with fresh milk. This was a supply of fresh milk for the family. This was a supply of fresh milk for the family.

16. **WRAPPINGS AND CONTAINERS**

Mention any changes which you recall in the wrappings and containers received with the food you purchased (give dates where possible).

*Mostly paper bags*

17. Give a typical daily menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

*Breakfast: porridge, eggs*
*Dinner: meat & potatoes, pudding for dessert*
*Supper: meat & meat, syrup*

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in Eastern Canada? .................. Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at that time.

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details. *no*
17. On a typical day, name (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest
member of the family. Name the year and list the members of the family
in order of age. Include the grandparents, cousins, etc., either
by name or by relationship.

18. That year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in January? If so,
give the date. List those present and give their ages.

19. Have you ever noticed almost starvation in local produce? Give details.
